# Draft:Presidential Secretary for Protocol

}}
The Presidential Secretary for Protocol is a position within the Office of the President (South Korea), responsible for overseeing the president’s official schedule and state protocol affairs. The role reports directly to the Chief Presidential Secretary and works alongside other key aides such as the Secretary for General Affairs, Secretary for Speechwriting, and the First and Second Personal Secretaries to support the president’s daily operations.
Functions
The Secretary for Protocol plans and coordinates all official schedules and events involving the President of South Korea. Responsibilities include arranging meetings with foreign dignitaries, state visits, ceremonial functions, and managing the president’s physical movement during public appearances.
The position is considered one of the most crucial support roles in the Office of the President, as it oversees the intersection of political messaging, ceremonial protocol, and logistical execution. Kwon Hyuk-ki was appointed to this role during the Lee Jae-myung administration and is noted for incorporating his prior experience in speechwriting and campaign media strategy into the position.
The role requires close coordination with the Presidential Security Service to ensure the safety and confidentiality of movements and event locations.
Typical duties include:
* Planning and execution of official events including schedules, locations, movement routes, and ceremonial order
* Organizing welcoming ceremonies and reception protocols for domestic and foreign guests
* Coordinating press coverage and photo opportunities
* Drafting and enforcing protocol guidelines during state visits
Position in the organization
The Protocol Secretary reports directly to the Chief Presidential Secretary and operates in close physical and administrative proximity to the president. The secretary frequently accompanies the president during diplomatic meetings and national addresses, effectively functioning as a principal external affairs aide.
History
While similar roles have existed under various administrations with different titles and structures, the term "Presidential Secretary for Protocol" was formally adopted following a reorganization of the presidential office in 2013. Since then, the position has served as the main operative in charge of managing presidential scheduling and ceremonial logistics across successive governments.
